body.p: Every time you look in the mirror, you get a glimpse of one of the body’s most essential and dynamic systems: the integumentary system. The integumentary system is made up of the skin and its accessory structures, and it is responsible for much more than simply lending you your outward appearance. In the adult human body, the skin makes up about 16 percent of the body weight and covers an area of 1.5 to 2 square meters. In fact, the skin and its accessory structures make up the largest organ system in human anatomy. While we do not typically think of the skin as an organ, it is made up of tissues that come together as a single structure to perform unique and critical functions. This unit will introduce you to the structures and functions of the integumentary system, and will describe diseases, disorders, and injuries that can affect the integumentary system.

section.title: Major Functions of the Integumentary System

body.p: The skin and its accessory structures perform a variety of essential functions, such as protecting the body from environmental elements and the invasion of microorganisms, acting as sensory mechanisms, and modulating body temperature. Skin also has other functions, including maintaining electrolyte balance, synthesizing vitamin D, storing lipids and fats for energy, and excreting toxins.

The skin protects the rest of the body from the basic elements of nature like wind, water, and radiation from the sun. It acts as a protective barrier against water loss due to the presence of keratin in cells and oils secreted to the surface, which make it naturally water resistant. It also is the first line of defense against mechanical abrasion and irritation caused by contact with parasites or harmful chemicals. Sweat excreted from sweat glands deters microbes from thriving on the skin surface by generating dermcidin, which has antibiotic properties. Sweat also helps with thermoregulation by cooling the body.

section.title: Common Dysfunctions of the Integumentary System

body.p: Skin cancer – Cancers are most common in epithelial tissues because of several issues: they may contain stem cells which have high mitotic rates, and are most vulnerable to DNA damage during mitosis. Also, epidermal epithelial cells are exposed to UV radiation and other environmental factors since they interface with the environment. The stratum basale, one epithelial layer found in the skin, can be the source of skin cancers such as basal cell carcinomas.

Burns – The skin acts as a barrier to the environment. Thermal, chemical and radiation burn traumas that destroy the skin tissue often lead to infections because of the loss of the skin's barrier function.
Bedsores – Also called decubitus ulcers, these sores develop when regions of the skin start dying because constant pressure limits blood flow to that region of the skin.

Psoriasis and acne – There are many skin conditions that are caused by a dysfunction of normal integumentary processes. The overproduction of skin cells results in psoriasis, and acne is caused by an infected or clogged sebaceous gland.

Calluses and scars – Like many systems of the body, the integumentary system is able to adapt to its external environment. Calluses are thickened skin that accumulates in areas of continued mechanical abrasion. Scars are caused by excess fibrous tissue being deposited when repairs are made to cuts in the skin.
These conditions and more will be covered as you learn about normal function of the integumentary system.
